citeinfo.title: Mercer County, New Jersey land parcels, 2009

descript.abstract: This GIS polygon feature data set was developed for Mercer County, New Jersey, USA, and contains tax parcels. The parcels were originally created using DVRPC digital orthophotgraphy at a scale of 1"=200' and scanned taxed maps which were geo-referenced to the digital orthophotography. Several update cycles of the parcel layer have been conducted, with the most recent referencing the 2007 orthophotography from the New Jersey State office of GIS.
descript.purpose: The purpose of this polygon feature data set is to assist Mercer County Departments.This data set was created to provide the bounding limits for each lot extent, based on the municipality's tax maps. The parcels become the means by which parcel ownership may be linked to tax assessor's data using block and lot attributes. Once linked, the user may retrieve ownership information through queries. The parcels may be used for display purposes when creating hard copy maps for reports, presentations, and working projects. This data set provides one of the key framework data sets in an overall GIS implementation strategy.
descript.supplinf: NJ Municipalities in Mercer County: East Windsor Boro, Ewing Twp, Hamilton Twp, Hightstown Boro, Hopewell Boro, Hopewell Twp, Lawrence Twp, Pennington Boro, Princeton Boro, Princeton Twp, Robbinsville Twp, Trenton City, West Windsor Twp

idinfo.useconst: Any maps, publications, reports, or other documents produced that utilize this data set will credit Mercer County, New Jersey office as the source of the data. Data are licensed to Princeton University-affiliated persons only.

cntorgp.cntorg: Map and Geospatial Information Center, Lewis Library, Princeton University

idinfo.datacred: Created by Civil Solutions, a division of ARH
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.2.0.3348

attracc.attraccr: Attribute accuracy is tested by manually comparing the digital data with the source materials using a heads-up method. Block and lot numbers are checked against county tax records to look for any discrepencies.

dataqual.logic: Data topology has been built and maintained through predefined rules applied by the user to ensure that there are no overlaps and gaps between parcel boundaries.
dataqual.complete: Data is as complete as the source data allow.

procstep.procdesc: Hard copy tax maps were scanned and saved as .tif files. These files were then imported into AutoCAD rel. 14 and using the CAD Overlay extension, the images were geo-referenced to the New Jersey State Plane NAD 83 coordinate system. The image file is then exported and a World File (.tfw) is created in association with the .tif image file. Using the digital orthophotography and the geo-referenced tax map image file, linework is added by heads-up digitized using AutoCAD rel. 14. Linework is set to different layers to facilitate the GIS processing once data capture is complete. Snaps are on at all times to ensure polygons are closed. After completion of digitizing linework, ArcCAD is loaded into the users profile. A program is run which compiles the file and processes the data into a GIS format. This file is then inserted into an ArcView GIS project where a shapefile is created using an export tool. The shapefile is checked using a QA/QC process. Any errors reported are corrected, the GIS process is run again and a final QA/QC process is repeated. If no errors are found, the file is complete.

As part of the New Jersey Office of Information Technology, Office of GIS (OGIS) effort to develop a statewide composite of parcel data sets, parcels sharing boundaries with municipal boundaries were modified to be coincident to the municipal boundaries data developed in 2008 by OGIS and adopted by GIS users throughout the state. Parcel boundaries that cross municipal boundaries were also modified to properly align at and across the municipal boundary. Three additional attribute fields were added to the attribute table to help note changes that occurred as a result of this process. They include a field to store the original size of the parcel before editing, a field to store the percentage change in area size, and a field to code parcels that were significantly altered in size and/or shape. After parcel geometry edits were completed, the area percentage change was calculated by comparing the size of the original area to the modified area using the following calculation, ([Shape_Area] / [OriginalAREA]) *100. Each parcel with a value below 90 percent and above 110 percent was considered significant and reviewed more closely against 2007/2008 orthophotography and municipal tax maps to determine if the parcel modification was appropriate. If, upon further inspection, the parcel modification was not consistent with the dimensions or acreage values shown on tax maps and/or orthophotography, the parcel (and neighboring parcels, if necessary) was again modified to minimize the size and/or shape distortion of the polygon. After additional editing, the area change was recalculated. If the recalculated change was still outside of the acceptable distortion level, the parcel was given a production code with an explanation for why the shape and/or area of the parcel was altered to a significant degree. Definitions for the production codes were given to each data steward to assist in their review of the data. The three additional attribute fields added to the attribute table to help note changes were deleted before final delivery of the data set to the data steward and OGIS.

cntaddr.address: 800 S White Horse Pike, PO Box 579

procstep.procdesc: Updates to the parcel layer have been made using source data gathered from each municipality within the County. Quality control/quality assurance methods were developed and used throughout the entire parcel update process. Topology rules were applied to ensure proper connectivity between polygons. During this parcel update, attempts were made to correct the alignment of the parcels with the 2007 NJ State orthophotography. Alignment of the parcels to recent orthophotography has been a problem since it was found that the original orthophotography from DVRPC in 2000 was flawed. This resulted in some parcels located as much as 30 feet away from their true ground location. For this cycle of parcel updates, all tax blocks that contained a parcel update were reviewed against the 2007 orthophotography. Changes to the parcel location and shape were made if necessary and all parcels reviewed were coded for future reference. The remaining parcels that do not match orthophotography will be corrected during future update cycles.
Converted to an ArcView Shapefile from an ArcGIS9.3 Personal GeoDatabase Feature Class using ArcToolbox (Conversion Tools - To Shapefile) Feature Class To Shapefile.
